Tamoxifen didn't work for me. I had my oompherectomy Nov 2010 and have been on Arimedex ever since. Aredia monthly from the start. Just to chime in that AI's can work really well even if tamoxifen doesn't do it for you. Good luck with your treatment.

Posts.Title: NEVER thought it would happen.. I have a boyfriend!! JeninMichigan seaperch

Posts.Content: Mar 16, 2013 10:49AM - edited Mar 16, 2013 10:52AM by Just_Sue Lots of interesting posts here. I haven't had the (dis)pleasure of the "it's your fault you have cancer because you haven't taken Jesus Christ as your savior" warped version of Christianity. I have been hit by the scorn of the spiritual-but-not-religious former friend. She was a big believer of positive thinking. Of note: --"I am a true believer in the mind body connection." "I don't believe in Western medicine." "Some people are not evolved enough (and wise like me) to see the truth." Etc... Is it wrong to feel insulted when western medicine is keeping me alive? Is it wrong for me to scoff at her evolved wisdom when she needs my help moving her canned cat food from her kitchen because she is "allergic" to "feathered creatures"? Thankfully she had another friend remove her down pillows. --When I mentioned that I found comfort in these boards, she was horrified. "You shouldn't be dwelling in all that negativity!" Talk about missing the point. --When she asked with a smile if I was cured, I told her the truth. The medicine is working for now and that is good, but someday it will fail and I worry sometimes about what form that failure will take. "Oh." By mutual decision, my friend and I have parted ways. She seemed to believe I was wallowing in grief and perpetuating my own illness. My other friends seem to be amazed at my general cheerfulness, go figure. My form of positivity includes not burying my head in the sand. It makes me feel better to have a better understanding of what may come. The form of positivity that her "spirituality" advises is just false. I refuse.
Posts.Title: Just think positive... BouncingBetties PinkShirtNow

Posts.Content: Jan 15, 2013 02:11AM Just_Sue wrote: Hi all.  Was diagnosed a few days before my 40th back in June 2010.  Turns out I was Stage IV from the get go with asymptomatic "bubbles" to my spine & pelvis.  I have 7 year old twins (B. 2005). One boy and one girl.  I am an Architect with my own small firm, focusing on residential design.  I am responding well with daily Arimedex and monthly Aridia.  After a couple of years of turmoil, my goal in 2013 is to focus a bit more on my business.  I have a new steady job lined up and am starting marketing for new work.  Extremely happy that my health is stable enough right now that I feel that I can make some new short term commitments.  Aiming for 20-30 hours per week so I still will have energy to be an active Mom.
Posts.Title: Roll Call 2013 LilSchatzie reader123

Posts.Content: Jan 23, 2013 10:45AM Just_Sue wrote: I did use the lump to determine that I progressed on Tamoxofin.  They did a follow up ultrasound and measured it.  It was slightly bigger than the baseline.  I am now on Arimedex with bone mets that barely show up on scans.  I like having the lump so that there is something easy and non-invasive to measure as one way to determine when it is time to move to another medication.  That said, at my last appointment with my MO, she explained to me that cancer progression is unpredictable.  The original lump could stay the same or even shrink but the bone mets may expand or grow or the mets could travel somewhere else like the liver or lungs etc.  For now we are keeping an eye on my tumor markers, watching the lump, feeling the liver and are on a symptom watch. So to answer your question, it can be an indicator of what is going on with your cancer but it is not the only indicator.
Posts.Title: Is your lump a good indicator of what's going on? 4myangels Just_Sue

Posts.Content: Mar 11, 2012 02:56PM Just_Sue wrote: Hi Rengeko, I wanted to say that I hear you. I am struggling with depression and a pending move as well. I have just started on the path of trying to help myself with the depression, finally getting on anti-depressants and seeing a therapist.  Don't have much advice on that since I am at the beginning of that journey.  I have been stage IV  for almost two years now.  There have been both physical and emotional ups and downs during that time.  I can tell you that when I am physically facing challanges, starting a new medicine, having tests, facing surgery, I usually can emotionally rally to get into the fighting mindset.  My lowest emotional times have been when I get good reports of no progression strangely enough.  I get in the whats the point, there is nothing but an inevitable decline for me...sob, cry.  Hopefully the therapist will be able to help me with that.  The point being,  this disease sucks.  It sucks when things are going bad, It sucks when things are going well. When things are in transition, it makes things even harder. Being depressed about it is natural.  Focus on something positive every day even if it is hard.  I know it will be hard being a visitor for a week but focus on the fact that your friend is there for you to help you transition. Sounds like a keeper.  I wish you all the best. Susan

Posts.Content: Jul 5, 2012 09:36PM Just_Sue wrote: When I was first diagnosed, my team was talking about seeing the grandchildren. At the time my twins were 5. Then they found the mets and they said the grandchildren were unrealistic but I could get years. (vague but optimistic) My first progression was after only 3 months. After about a year on my second drug my MO confided that she thought at the start, since I was young at diagnosis (39) and I progressed so quickly on the first round that my cancer was much more aggressive than it is turning out to be. You never know. I am hopeful that I will see my kids graduate. It may not happen but I am living life and making plans like I'll be sticking around.

Posts.Content: Apr 5, 2012 02:35PM Just_Sue wrote: Hi Kayrnic,  Sorry to hear about the mets.  I was diagnosed Stage IV from the start almost two years ago with mets to the spine. I was 39 as well, a few days from my 40th birthday.  I have been on hormonals exclusively in that time, first tamoxifen, which only worked for a few months and then I had my ovaries removed around Thanksgiving 2010 and have been on Arimedex ever since.  I wanted to let you know that hormonals can be very effective.  I had a pretty large tumor, over 5cm.  My most recent scans show a reduction of about 90%.   I was advised by my oncologist brother to visuallize the battle at stage IV as a marathon rather than a sprint.   I always think that Stage IV is upside down from the earlier stages. In earlier stages you suffer through the most aggressive treatment that you can stand and then it is over and you are a survivor. A sprint.  In stage IV, the doctors in general seem to start with the least toxic treatments (hormonals when you are er+) and then move towards to the chemos after the hormonals fail. You start out with the survival stage, living your life as best as you can with the cancer hopefully as far in the background as you can get it.  It is really, really hard, especially at first but you WILL find your way. You should talk to your doctor(s) more about the mascetomy and reconstruction to see what they have to say.  My doctor wanted to keep the primary tumor in order to have a better barameter in terms of how the cancer is reacting to the medicine.  I agreed and am happy with the decision to avoid that surgery.  I consider it my early warning system and it gives me a sence of security.  I know that alot of people feel the opposite and want to purge all of the cancer from their body.  It is a personal decision. I agree with the above post to question your doctor about all of their treatment recommendations and get a second opinion if possible. I wish you all the best. Susan

Posts.Content: Sep 12, 2012 12:23PM Just_Sue wrote: Sorry to hear about your side effects on Zometa.  I've been on Pamidronate (Aridia) for two years.  I had a few side effects at the beginning, just feeling blah, but they have gone away now.  My infusion nurse said that it was pretty typical for people to complain for the first three months, but get used to it and have fewer problems after that.  My only advice is to drink lots of water, before and after.  Good luck.

Posts.Content: Jan 24, 2012 06:39PM Just_Sue wrote: Yes it is possible to be Stage IV and pretty much symptom free.  At diagnosis my MO ordered a bone scan and CT to help determine staging.  Both came back irregular yet inconclusive.  Conclusive diagnosis came after a bone biopsy to the spine.  The little "bubbles" were bone mets.  My surgery was cancelled and here I am 19 months later and still pretty much symptom free.  Go figure.  Good Luck, Susan

Posts.Content: Feb 7, 2013 02:08AM Just_Sue wrote: Hi Chris1959, My onc. says the same thing as yours regarding scans... Scan if there are any changes to either symptoms or tumor markers.  My markers did rise on the one time that there was progression.  My markers are currently holding steady at 12-13 for over a year.  I have no symptoms.  I see my oncologist every three months and she feels me up, primary tumor, nodes and liver.  I am bone only and the cancer barely shows up on the scans at all anyways.   It is odd because everybody here does get scans regularly.  My last scan was in November of 2010!  At this point I am comfortable with the no scan decision but I do ask her every three months when I see her.  I do not feel that my doctor is unresponsive.  I know if I e-mail and tell her that I have some unusual pain or fatique she would schedule a scan the next day.

Posts.Content: Nov 7, 2011 08:11PM Just_Sue wrote: Hi Lisa,  Welcome to the board.  Sorry you are here.  I was diagnosed stage IV with bone mets and started on tamoxifen which didn't require my ovaries to be removed.  It worked for only a very short time and after 4 monthes had my Ovaries removed and started on Arimidex.  The new drug has been working well for me for almost a year.  So as to your question, yes hormone therapy can really work.  I recently had a 90% reduction in my primary tumor.  It is however very individual and may or may not work work for you.  Try not to get discouraged if it fails, you may be able to try another hormonal before you move onto chemo.  I haven't had any chemo or surgery yet so I only chime in on hormonal treatment.  I am a fan.  Good luck with the biopsy and I hope your treatment works well for you.
Posts.Title: Hormone therapy ? mylifelisa Chickadee

Posts.Content: Oct 3, 2012 12:17AM Just_Sue wrote: Hi Lulu, I was diagonsed at Stage IV with bone mets from the get go when I had just turned 40.  Tamoxifen failed after only 3 months.  I had an oomp. and started Arimedex which has worked well.  It will be two years this coming Thanksgiving.  I just wanted to chime in so that you know that your proposed treatment can be very successful.  I would also see about a bone strenthener.  I am on Aredia but I think Zometa and Xgeva are more common. I wish you all the best, Susan

Posts.Content: Sep 11, 2012 10:17AM Just_Sue wrote: Welcome to Stage IV. Sorry you are here. Time is the only thing to settle into your new life.  Continuing to live, working, going on vacations, making plans a few months in the future, these are good things. By all means, get your affairs in order as well.  You will feel better once you don't have to worry about that.  If the tumor markers are a sign that your current treatment is not working, you will switch it up until something clicks for you.  Good luck to you.
